Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Single Crystal X-ray Diffractometer at the University of Virginia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. The University of Virginia (UVA) is acquiring a single crystal X-ray diffractometer to support Professor Robert Gilliard and colleagues: Thomas Gunnoe and Diane Dickie. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles. It provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate and graduate students in chemistry and biochemistry as well as other engineering fields at this institution. In addition, the diffractometer has broad impact on teaching and training, outreach activities, and undergraduate research at UVA. The regional partners from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) have significant female and underrepresented minority populations the also benefit from the use of this instrumentation.

The award of the X-ray diffractometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. The instrument acquisition impacts the characterization of synthetic inorganic and organic materials useful to advance manufacturing. The instrumentation is used for studying catalytic processes and using electrochemistry to generate energy relevant products, e.g., conversion of low potential energy chemicals into high energy chemicals for the scaled use of renewable energy sources such as wind, solar. In addition, the diffractometer benefits the exploration of materials chemistry and engineering. It is also used to characterize products relevant to biological chemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Bruker D8 Venture micro-focus dual source single crystal X-ray diffractometer with a PhotonIII detector was installed in late March 2021. Single crystal X-ray diffractometers are primarily used to determine the 3-D structure of new molecules created by synthetic chemists. Knowing the structure of a molecule is the first step towards understanding the properties of the molecule. The molecules that have been studied with our diffractometer may someday be used as new medicines or new catalysts for green energy development. They are also molecules that simply help us discover the basic rules of how atoms connect to one another. 

After less than three years of operation, data collected on this diffractometer has already appeared in 40 peer-reviewed journal articles. Other research output includes at least 19 oral and/or poster presentation at local, regional, national and international conferences, 4 Ph.D. dissertations, and 9 non-peer-reviewed depositions to the Cambridge Structural Database. The main users of the diffractometer come from the University of Virginia's Department of Chemistry, with 53 students and postdocs from 8 different labs having submitted research samples for diffraction studies. Approximately half of them are fully or partially trained to collect data independently. The diffractometer also serves a large number of researchers outside of the chemistry department. It has attracted users from 16 different groups in the UVA departments of Physics, Chemical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Materials Science, and from the School of Medicine. Finally, we have users from 11 other universities in Virginia, Georgia, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, and one start-up business in Virginia.

The diffractometer is also a crucial component of the university's teaching mission. In particular, a graduate-level class in X-ray crystallography, CHEM 5380 – Determination of Molecular Structure by Diffraction Methods. This class has been offered four times since the installation of the diffractometer, serving 58 undergraduate and graduate students. All have had multiple hand-on experiences with the diffractometer. The diffractometer is also featured in annual visits to the X-ray diffraction lab by students from the UVA Environmental Sciences department  Geochemistry (EVGE 5850) and Isotope Geochemistry (EVGE 5860) classes. There is also an ongoing collaboration with Clark University’s CHEM 250 class (Inorganic Chemistry) wherein the students send samples by mail to be run on the diffractometer with one data collection done live on Zoom for them to see.
